This possibility of having to depend on *oonarchist support may have
helped to account for the vigor and extent of Fanfani*s assault on the Commun¬
ists in his program speech. He may have wanted to assure conservatives in his

common with those of the Communists or the fellow-traveling Jociallats.
There was one more subtlety in the situation that may have figured in
Fanfani*a attack on the Communists. It involved Pietro Henni and his Sociali¬
sts. At one point there i/ere reports that because of Fanfani1® left-wing re¬
putation, the 75 Nenni Socialists might abstain from the vote of confidence
altogether. Ibis, of course, would have reduced Fanfanl,s mathematical pro¬
blem.
But for obvious political reasons, the Christian Democrats felt they could
not afford a government that would depend for its support on the tacit consent,
if not active support, of Henni. It was reported, therefore, that if Fanfani
survived in the Chamber only because the Socialists abstained, his own Chris¬
tian Democratic party would engineer his downfall in the Senate.
By sailing into the Communists in his program speech, Fanfani made it
impossible for the Henni Socialists to do anything but oppose him vigorously.
And thus, in his final speech before the vote, Fanfani cited this Socialist*
opposition as one more proof that Nennl is, in fact, the Captive of the
Communists.
veil, as overyone now knows, all of Fanfani1® Juggling and compromising
was in vain. He started out with a total of 24? sure votes against him — 143
Comunists, 75 Nennl Socialists and 29 neo-Faaciata.
Of the votes from the other parties that he tried for, Fanfani got only
the five of the Republicans.
By leaving the door only slightly ajar instead of inviting them cordi¬
ally into the house, he lost the 40 Monarchists.
That left it up to the Social Democrats, who might have been expected to
back him as a social reformer. But the Social Democrats have not recovered
from the shock of the 1953 Elections, when they loot heavily to the Henni
Socialists. They are convinced that one reason for those losses was their
previous collaboration with — and oerhaps subservience to — the Christian
Democrats.
They demanded that Fanfani come out for a new electoral law, based on
strict proportional representation, which they believe would help them. This
Fanfani was unable to do because of opposition in his own party.
